4.2a.definition: a type of programming language that uses English-like commands.
a language closer to the machine's language, this could be assembly language or binary code.
a program that can be run on different types and manufacturers of computers.
a program that cannot be run on different types and manufacturers of computers.

4.2b.definition: binary code, an example of a low-level language.
code written in mnemonics that allows direct manipulation of the hardware. It must be converted into binary code to run.
instruction code used in assembly language.

4.2c.definition: converts a program written in a high-level language program into machine code
converts assembly language into machine code.
a computer program that analyses and executes a program written in a high-level language line by line
a computer program that translates a source program written in a high-level language to machine code
a file produced by a compiler that can be run independent of translator software and does not include the source code.

4.2e.definition: a piece of software that allows a user to write, test and run program code.
a feature of an IDE that allows the user to enter and amend program code.
a feature of an editor that gives the user options when they start typing a command.
a feature of an editor that identifies spelling errors and changes them.
a feature of an editor that changes the colour of text, for example, to highlight key words.
displaying source code using different colours and formatting, which make the code easier to read and understand
a feature of an IDE that allows a program to be run and lets the user interact with the program.
a separate window in the runtime environment of an IDE that shows the contents of variables during the execution of a program
finding errors in a computer program by running or tracing the program
